Problem:
Nvim crashes on receive SIGTSTP (Ctrl-Z) since 4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81.

Solution:
* Don't exit on SIGTSTP (not a deadly signal).
* Avoid SIGTSTP handler in os/signal.c.

Co-authored-by: 27Onion Nebell <zzy20080201@gmail.com>

body:
Problem: after
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81,
neovim quit and crash on receive SIGTSTP (Ctrl-Z).

Solution: Don't exit on SIGTSTP (not a deadly signal).

Fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33254.

comment_data.body: Should we drop this for now, given https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33258#issuecomment-2772231011 ? May need to adjust a test. And remove SIGTSTP from news.txt.
Yeah I think it couldn't be merged until we solved this problem, and although i kinda figured out why it doesn't work it seems to be really tricky to fix. Maybe need to turn it into a draft for now.

Not enough to remove this line, we need also remove all the code that registers (and the corresponding cleanup code) `SIGTSTOP` handler, or it will still be a blink. As long as the handler exists, we need to suspend by ourselves.

> Not enough to remove this line, we need also remove all the code that registers (and the corresponding cleanup code) `SIGTSTOP` handler, or it will still be a blink. As long as the handler exists, we need to suspend by ourselves.

It's basically reverting most of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81 (since it mainly adding handlers for `SIGSTOP`, along with some other stuffs)
Sure, let's revert all `sigstp`-related changes from that commit. But the changes for the other signals can stay.

> Sure, let's revert all `sigstp`-related changes from that commit. But the changes for the other signals can stay.

I checked that commit carefully and confirmed that it's just all about adding handlers to `SIGTSTP` (and adding corresponding tests and documentation), so if removing the code is preferred solution, then it's just revert this commit and all done
Oh wait... I might find out a nice solution that can preserve this feature and also pause `nvim` normally. I'm going to run tests now.

without `SIGTSTP`, the `autowrite_all()` won't be called, which defeats the purpose of your other change.
```suggestion
  kill(0, SIGTSTP);  // Triggers autowrite_all() in os/signal.c.
  kill(0, SIGSTOP);
```

Weirdly though, I ran the test `test/functional/autocmd/signal_spec.lua` (which contains checks of autowrite) with `kill(0, SIGTSTP)` removed, and it seems to be totally fine... Anyway, let's see the test.

Edit: It also doesn't affect functionality at all because I tested at the very beginning when I started to working on it.

Oops. It seems the author pushed the change very quickly. It might be better to see the test result and then comment on it. Anyway I tested a lot on it and it *seems* adding or deleting the `kill(0, SIGTSTP)` doesn't affect anything though, including the functional tests (at least on my machine).

...also begging that ubuntu's tests don't have weird unrelated errors.

Ctrl-Z -> `nv_suspend` -> `do_cmdline` -> `ex_stop` -> `tui_suspend` (ui) -> `on_signal`
I'm a bit confusing... `ex_stop` has already a `auto_writeall` in it: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f4ee0ab2f1a15fe3bb88122fa162620e4af74b1d/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c#L5080-L5088

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81 add this because it want to handle it from a `kill -TSTP server_pid`?
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81/test/functional/autocmd/signal_spec.lua#L35-L40

Another thing: `kill -TSTP client_pid` now no longer ~detach~"stop" the ui. But it will before https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81.

> `ex_stop` has already a `auto_writeall` in it:

ok, makes sense. So we can drop the `kill(0, SIGTSTP);` in tui.c.

> Another thing: `kill -TSTP client_pid` now no longer ~detach~"stop" the ui. But it will before [4dabeff](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/4dabeff308222307ede8e74a2bd341713a7f7d81).

I think that's quite fair since we don't stop the UI in the signal handler, we only did that in UI's event handler. We may need to call some function on such signal to stop the UI as if the user is stopping it, maybe.

comment_regular_data.body: It's great that it doesn't crash anymore, but when I press `C-z` it just blink and then returned to `nvim`... rather than being paused normally, returning to shell and be able to resume again using `fg`

That's true... I didn't notice this. Since I'm using a wrapper.
```
echo 'VIMRUNTIME=runtime ./build/bin/nvim -u NONE' > wrapper.sh
bash ./wrapper.sh
```
No idea why now and I will debug for a while...

> That's true... I didn't notice this. Since I'm using a wrapper.
> 
> ```
> echo 'VIMRUNTIME=runtime ./build/bin/nvim -u NONE' > wrapper.sh
> bash ./wrapper.sh
> ```
> 
> No idea why now and I will debug for a while...

It seems that once signal caught by libuv, it can no longer act normally as if it is not called after handling (...?) hence to make it function normally, we have to find a way to either actively suspend the process by ourselves or somehow trigger the default behavior of that signal.

As for why the wrapper works, that's probably because `SIGTSTP` was sent to the interpreter of the script file instead of neovim.

I found a fix that works, but not modifying `src/nvim/os/signal.c`.

Just fire a `SIGSTOP` after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3af43cffa028b88022e6bdc78a4e2f5470643219/src/nvim/tui/tui.c#L1579 . And `C-z` now works perfectly.

For me I just copy-pasted last code and changed `SIGTSTP` to `SIGSTOP`, i.e.
```c
kill(0, SIGTSTP); // <-- The original code
kill(0, SIGSTOP);
```

> Sure let's try it

Some tests broke on my machine but I reran the tests with my changes discarded and same tests breaks, hence my change doesn't introduce any new bugs, so I guess it's time to call the author of the PR @phanen that this fix works perfectly.

The ubuntu's tests looks concerning....
But it's unlikely caused by my code i guess.

Also may I request a co-author on the pull request if it can be merged (?) :point_right: :point_left:

Failed test looks irrelated. I'm not sure I understand what happened... because libuv won't catch SIGSTOP? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bd0a65bc151a7a496e913125f54814f591845e91/runtime/doc/luvref.txt#L1234.

And can we just delete `SIGTSTP`? It seems skipped for unkown reason...

> Failed test looks irrelated. I'm not sure I understand what happened... because libuv won't catch SIGSTOP?
> 
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bd0a65bc151a7a496e913125f54814f591845e91/runtime/doc/luvref.txt#L1234
> .

Exactly. Since `SIGTSTP` is catched and doesn't work anymore, we just trigger `SIGSTOP` manually to fix that.

> 
> And can we just delete `SIGTSTP`? It seems skipped for unkown reason...

Don't quite understand wdym...? If you're talking about the handler, removing the handler will break the `functionaltest` (added by *that* commit). If you're talking about the `kill(0, SIGTSTP)`, I actually didn't test it. You can try removing it and run `functionaltest`, see if `test/functional/autocmd/signal_spec.lua` breaks. If it didn't, then probably fine.


P.S. Why I'm preserving the `kill(0, SIGTSTP)` is because, firstly I'm just lazy to run the tests again (it takes a lot of time lmao), and I presume removing it might cause the handler not being ran so I don't want to take the risk. Also the pausing functionality seems to be working very well even if I don't remove it so I decided not to touch it.
I'm very wary of calling `do_cmdline_cmd` from as signal handler. Let's try that in a separate followup PR, if at all.
